The minimum difficulty for this roll is 1. If the victim's player fails this roll, the victim is stunned, losing two dice from all non-reflexive rolls until the attacker's next action. The effects of this Boon apply to any attack the character makes — whether melee or ranged — for which he spends the necessary Legend point.

SUN.NAME: SUN
SUN.DESCRIPTION:
This Purview represents the brilliance of the sun, its constancy, and its celestial glory.
Associated With: Amaterasu, Apollo, Atum-Re, Baldur, Bastet, Freyr, Heimdall, Horus, Huitzilopochtli, Legba, Tezcatlipoca

PENETRATING_GLARE.NAME: PENETRATING GLARE
PENETRATING_GLARE.DESCRIPTION: Just as sunlight only dims when passing through thick clouds, a Scion's vision can also pierce physical occlusions. When the Scion receives this Boon, she sees clearly through physical impediments like smoke, fog, murky water (if the Scion is in said water), or even translucent barriers through which other people might see only silhouettes. The character can even see perfectly clearly in dim light (i.e., light no less intense than a single birthday candle). In total darkness, however, she is as blind as the next person.

DIVINE_RADIANCE.NAME: DIVINE RADIANCE
DIVINE_RADIANCE.DESCRIPTION:
This Boon allows a Scion to emit sunlight. She can radiate a glow from her entire body, shining with the intensity of a 100-watt incandescent bulb, or focus that light into a narrower beam. For example, she could narrow the focus of the light to come from her palm or her eyes to act as a high-powered flashlight. The Scion can emit soft light in this way for a scene.
Alternatively, the character can concentrate her light into a single intense burst that glints off some reflective surface on her person, be it the steel edge of her weapon, the metal buttons of her jacket, or the surgical steel head of her tongue piercing. (Such a burst imposes a -2 distraction penalty on the victim's non-reflexive actions until the Scion's next action, and ends the Scion's use of this Boon.) The Scion could even focus the light into a point intense enough to burn an object or ignite a flammable accelerant. (The point is not intense enough to cause damage to a victim in combat, however.)

HEAVENLY_FLARE.NAME: HEAVENLY FLARE
HEAVENLY_FLARE.DESCRIPTION: Concentrating for one action (Speed 4), the Scion builds and releases a flash of sunlight that is impossible for anyone within line of sight to miss. When she does this, the player of anyone who was looking at her, even through expensive sunglasses, must roll (Stamina + Fortitude). If the victim's roll obtains more successes than the Scion's activation roll, he sees only a sudden flash that has no effect on him. If the victim obtains an equal number of successes, he still suffers a -2 distraction penalty on all non-reflexive actions until the Scion's next action. If the Scion obtains more successes to activate this Boon than a victim to resist it, the victim is blinded and Inactive until the Scion's next action. Afterward, the victim suffers a -3 distraction penalty on all non-reflexive actions for a number of actions equal to the Scion's Legend rating. Extras are automatically considered to have failed the resistance roll.

WAR.NAME: WAR
WAR.DESCRIPTION:
This Purview covers all ideologically inspired battles, from the smallest house-to-house invasions to the most impressive land, sea, and air campaigns, to the greatest cosmic clash between God and Titan. The ideology in question must be religious, political, geographical, or cosmic for the conflict to qualify.
Associated With: Ares, Athena, Erzulie, Freya, Freyr, Hachiman, Huitzilopochtli, Odin, Ogoun, Set, Tezcatlipoca, Tyr

BLESSING_OF_BRAVERY.NAME: BLESSING OF BRAVERY
BLESSING_OF_BRAVERY.DESCRIPTION: Chanting a blessing over a person or group prepared to enter battle, the Scion bolsters their courage and resolve. Each character on the Scion's side of the conflict who hears the blessing gains a Willpower point, as well as two temporary bonus dots of Valor that last until the end of the battle. The Scion can amplify his voice electronically, but must be present at the battle and deliver the blessing live.

BATTLE_CRY.NAME: BATTLE CRY
BATTLE_CRY.DESCRIPTION:
During a battle, be it open field combat or an alley brawl between a Band of Scions and a gang of frost giants, the Scion can let out a horrifying battle cry that unnerves his enemies. Each fighter on the Scion's enemies' side who hears the supernatural cry loses one die from all attack rolls for a number of attacks equal to the Scion's Legend rating.
The Scion can use electronic equipment to amplify this battle cry so that all enemies present can hear it, but he himself must be present on the battlefield for it to work. He can let out this battle cry only once per combat scene, and it does not affect enemies whose Legend rating is higher than his.

WARRIOR_IDEAL.NAME: WARRIOR IDEAL
WARRIOR_IDEAL.DESCRIPTION: The Scion adopts some idealized warrior aspect, from howling berserker to unquestioning enlisted soldier, to fearless officer, to merciless samurai. This demeanor unnerves and intimidates any opponent who faces him in combat, inflicting a penalty equal to the Scion's Legend on any attack roll the opponent makes. This penalty applies to any character with a Legend rating lower or equal who attempts to attack the Scion. This idealized aspect lasts for a number of consecutive actions during the battle equal to the successes the Scion's player rolled to activate it, and he can invoke it only once during any battle.

WATER.NAME: WATER
WATER.DESCRIPTION:
Water is arguably the most important and versatile substance in the World. Only a few Gods claim dominion over this Purview, and they keep their secrets from all but their most trusted Scions.
Associated With: Poseidon, Quetzalcoátl, Sobek, Susano-o

WATER_BREATHING.NAME: WATER BREATHING
WATER_BREATHING.DESCRIPTION:
The Scion never needs to fear drowning, and is no longer affected by extremes of water temperature. She can breathe water as easily as air, and is not scalded by boiling water nor subject to debilitating burns from ice. Having boiling water poured on flesh still hurts, mind you, and being trapped in ice or drifting in frigid water can still numb and paralyze a Scion. Neither of these extremes can cause actual physical damage to the Scion, however.
When the Scion moves from air to water or vice versa, she must spend an Inactive action to purge one substance from her lungs and breathe the other. She can forestall this need through the normal rules for holding breath (on p. 182). If the Scion is breathing water, any toxins in that water affect her exactly as breathing airborne toxins would on land.

WATER_CONTROL.NAME: WATER CONTROL
WATER_CONTROL.DESCRIPTION:
For a number of actions equal to the successes on the activation roll, the Scion can exert limited physical control over any water touching her. She can remotely manipulate a portable object she can see in the water with her full dice pool, though she cannot perform other physical actions at the same time. She can harden the water under her feet to walk on its surface. She can even make the water push her from all sides, allowing her to execute a full Move action while swimming, instead of half (see p. 180 in Chapter Six). Alternatively, moving through water in this way could increase her Dodge DV by an amount equal to her Legend, provided she does nothing but dodge incoming attacks. The Boon also allows for random tricks, like making the Scion instantly dry off by throwing all the water off her body or creating a water bridge so an aquatic creature can swim from one container to another.
This Boon works only on liquid water, and a Scion can affect five cubic yards of water at a time per Legend point she possesses. (If she is walking on water, she can affect a 30’ x 15’ rectangle on the surface per Legend point she possesses. The affected area supports only her and anything she might be carrying unaided.) Her command is not such, however, that she can use water to restrain or inflict direct physical damage against an opponent with a liquid form of her creation.

CHANGING_STATES.NAME: CHANGING STATES
CHANGING_STATES.DESCRIPTION: Defying the laws of thermodynamics, the Scion can instantly change the state of a body of water just by touching it. With this Boon, she can take liquid water, steam, ice, or mist and transform any one into the other three. The amount of water she can affect is the same as in Water Control, and the water remains in its new state for a number of actions equal to the successes rolled to activate the Boon. Water under this effect is also subject to the Scion's Water Control, provided the Scion maintains contact with some part of it. The Scion can now inflict damage against a single opponent with blasts of steam or with ice projectiles, using her regular traits. (Damage for a steam blast is always lethal environmental damage [Damage: 2L/action, Trauma: 3], but damage can be bashing or lethal for an ice projectile.) The character can also create a club, axe, knife, or sword of ice and use it as a normal weapon of that type. Water in an altered state does not melt, freeze, boil, or condense as it normally would in its current environment for the duration of the effect. As altered steam, it maintains a constant temperature of 220 degrees; as altered liquid water or altered mist, it remains at 70 degrees; as altered ice, it remains at 14 degrees. (This is all in Fahrenheit, by the way.) When the effect ends, the water instantly resumes its original state and temperature.

PANTHEON_SPECIFIC.DESCRIPTION: These Boons are passed through a Scion's ichor — similar to Epic Attributes — so using them requires no Birthright items. No Scion can purchase or use a Pantheon-Specific Purview from outside his pantheon. Scions must purchase these Boons in sequence, but not separately. The Scion's player pays the experience for the next dot in the progression to receive the next individual power or power increase.

ARETE.NAME: ARETE
ARETE.DESCRIPTION:
Arete is a Greek word meaning “excellence”, a quality highly prized among the Greek Gods. Indeed, displaying superior skill or total command of a field of study is a recurring theme in many legends about them. Granted, most of those legends involve some pompous mortal claiming to be the best there is at what he does and an offended God's reaction to that claim not being very pretty. However, the Greek Gods and the society that worshipped them held the concept of excellence in such high regard that it became a specific Purview for them.
This Purview confers no specific powers, exactly, so much as it magnifies one's talents to divine proportions. When a Scion takes an Arete, he assigns one of his Abilities to it. (That Ability must be ranked at three dots or higher first.) From then on, whenever the Scion's player rolls a dice pool that includes the chosen Ability, the pool receives a number of bonus dice based on the number of dots he has of Arete. Alternatively, the Scion can sacrifice two of these bonus dice (provided he has at least two available) in exchange for a potential reroll should his first roll fail. If the roll on which he sacrificed two bonus dice doesn't have the good sense to fail, however, the player doesn't get to roll those bonus dice after the fact. Nor does he get to reroll a successful roll in hopes of scoring even more successes.
A character can have an Arete in any Ability (or as many Abilities) as he wants, but must buy the dots for each Ability's Arete separately. The dot-to-bonus dice exchange is as follows:

ARETE_2.NAME: ARETE (LEVEL 2)
ARETE_2.DESCRIPTION: Two bonus dice (or one potential reroll).

ARETE_3.NAME: ARETE (LEVEL 3)
ARETE_3.DESCRIPTION: Four bonus dice (or two potential rerolls).

CHEVAL.NAME: CHEVAL
CHEVAL.DESCRIPTION: With this Purview, a Scion can assume the role of “met tet” or master of the head spirit in a person's life. Scions of the Voodoo Loa should be responsible and use their powers only in service of their community, but these Boons raise a terrible temptation to do otherwise.

RADAS_EYES.NAME: RADA’S EYES
RADAS_EYES.DESCRIPTION:
The Scion can experience another person's perceptions as if they were her own. These perceptions include input from all five senses, though not the character's subjective reactions to that input. To use this Boon, the Scion must have a photo of her victim, some genetic symbol of the victim (like a lock of hair or several drops of blood), or something the victim created (from a printed email to an ice sculpture). By meditating on the item and relaxing her own perceptions — as well as spending a Legend point after a successful (Perception + Empathy) roll by her player — the Scion experiences the victim's perceptions clearly and distinctly. The victim is unaware of the Scion's attention, but the Scion remains semi-conscious of her own surroundings. The Scion's player is entitled to a (Perception + Awareness) roll to notice if something obvious is happening around her character, like if a zombie came stumbling toward her with a sizzling stick of dynamite. If something less obvious happens around the Scion, however — for example, anything that would require a (Perception + Awareness) roll to notice if she were paying full attention — the Scion does not notice while her perceptions are distracted.
A Scion can experience the perceptions of a mortal human being without being noticed, provided she has at least one of the required items. The same goes for a fellow Scion who has fewer Legend points than she does. If that fellow Scion has more Legend points, the character cannot experience his perceptions. If that fellow Scion has an equal number of Legend points, the Voodoo Scion needs a genetic symbol that belonged to the victim. Also, the victim's player is entitled to a (Perception + Awareness) roll. If that roll is successful, his character has the weird, vague sensation of being watched. If that character then spends a Willpower point, the Voodoo Scion loses her connection and cannot experience remote perceptions for the rest of the scene.

PETROS_HANDS.NAME: PETRO’S HANDS
PETROS_HANDS.DESCRIPTION:
The Scion can now exert some control over a victim whose senses she is observing. The Scion must be actively experiencing her victim's perceptions with Rada’s Eyes, and her player must spend a Willpower point to activate this Boon. If the Voodoo Scion's victim is a mortal or a Scion with fewer Legend points than she, activating this Boon requires only that Willpower expenditure. If the victim Scion has an equal number of Legend points, the Voodoo Scion's player must also succeed on a contested roll of her (Intelligence + Control) against the victim's (Willpower + Integrity + Legend). If she succeeds, the Voodoo Scion can then perform a physical action through the victim's body. She can do anything from simply forcing the victim to stand still and stare intently at something the Scion wants to study to making the oblivious victim jump out of the way of a shinobi assassin's flying kick. The dice pool for the action the Scion forces the victim to take is based on the Voodoo Scion's mundane traits. (Epic Attributes do not help the action.)
A Scion can exert this control over a victim only once per scene.

HORSE.NAME: HORSE
HORSE.DESCRIPTION:
The Scion can now exert full control over her victim for a limited time. She must be using Rada’s Eyes to share the victim's perceptions, and must spend a Willpower point and a Legend point to assert full control. (The victim's chance to resist is the same as for Petro’s Hands.) If the Scion succeeds in her possession attempt, she can “ride” inside her victim's body for a scene (or less if she chooses to end the effect early). She exerts all her own mundane traits, except Appearance, through the effectively empty shell, losing all sense of the situation around her own body. If the body she is riding suffers damage as a result of her actions, she feels the pain and suffers wound penalties, but it is only phantom psychosomatic pain. Her own body suffers no damage. Once the spirit horse's body suffers enough damage to render it Incapacitated or kill it (based on the host's own traits, not the Scion's), the Scion loses her connection to it and returns to her own body. If the Scion's actual body suffers damage as a result of something happening around her, the Scion remains unaware of it until her spirit returns home. If someone or some event destroys the Scion's body while her spirit is away, her spirit simply fades from existence.
A victim of possession has only dreamlike, glimpsed memories of what his body did when possessed. If the actions the Scion took were especially traumatic for the victim, the victim might block them out completely.

HEKU.NAME: HEKU
HEKU.DESCRIPTION: This Purview derives from the ancient Egyptian understanding of the metaphysical composition of the soul. According to this belief, the soul consists of the ren (name), sekem (energy), ba (soul/personality), ka (corporeal life force), akh (post-death union of ba and ka), khaibit (shadow), and sekhu (the physical remains of the body).

REN_HARVEST.NAME: REN HARVEST
REN_HARVEST.DESCRIPTION: Whenever someone speaks of the Scion's deeds, or whenever he sees news of his exploits printed somewhere, his player makes a (Charisma + Empathy) roll. The Scion gains a number of Legend points equal to the number of successes rolled. The story must pertain specifically to the Scion, which context should make clear. Furthermore, it must be uttered or written without the Scion's direct knowledge. He can reasonably expect to see or hear it, but cannot literally order someone to say or write it to reap the benefits. This Boon concerns only evidence that his legend is spreading — hence the reward in Legend points.

SEKEM_BLAZE.NAME: SEKEM BLAZE
SEKEM_BLAZE.DESCRIPTION:
Sekem is the light, power, and energy of the Scion's soul. With this Boon, he channels that powerful light through his gaze to cow an enemy. Such an enemy can be an animal, a person, a Scion, or even one of the titanspawn, and the Scion need only look him in the eye and spend a Legend point. An animal that sees the Sekem Blaze in the Scion's eyes immediately ceases any aggression toward the Scion and flees. A mortal or ghost so affected calms down and remains cowed for the rest of the scene. A Scion or titanspawn with fewer Legend points than the Scion using the Boon is as affected as a mortal, but a Scion or titanspawn with an equal number of points can spend a Willpower point to counteract the effect. Anyone with more Legend points remains unaffected.
A Scion can attempt to affect only one victim per action with this Boon. If the Scion attacks a victim he has cowed with this power, the effect ends after the aggressive action.

SEKEM_BARRIER.NAME: SEKEM BARRIER
SEKEM_BARRIER.DESCRIPTION: The character spends a Legend point and his player rolls (Appearance + Command). If the roll succeeds, the glow of the character's divine heritage illuminates his entire body, affecting everyone who looks at him. Use the same rubric as for Sekem Blaze to determine if nearby characters are affected. Those who are affected react like those affected by Sekem Blaze.

ITZTLI.NAME: ITZTLI
ITZTLI.DESCRIPTION: The Aztecs practiced many sacrificial rituals, from personal observances performed in private to public spectacles held on stone altars atop massive step pyramids. They did this to both empower and appease the Gods so that the Gods would have the means and motivation to continue doing their jobs. Being both mortal and divine, the Scion of an Aztec God can walk the line between performing and accepting a blood sacrifice.

MAGUEY_STING.NAME: MAGUEY STING
MAGUEY_STING.DESCRIPTION: Piercing her flesh with a maguey thorn, an obsidian blade, a surgical scalpel, or even just a rusty pin, the Scion sheds a portion of her blood. This blood serves as a symbolic offering to her divine parent, who rewards her with a single Legend point. The Scion can perform this sacrifice only once per day.

COMBAT_SACRIFICE.NAME: COMBAT SACRIFICE
COMBAT_SACRIFICE.DESCRIPTION:
The Scion stands unbowed before her raging enemies, sacrificing her safety in the name of her Legend. In combat, the character spends a Willpower point to psychologically prepare herself for an action that might seem like folly. The player then sacrifices DV points against an incoming attack, effectively making the character easier to hit. She cannot sacrifice more DV points than she has Legend points. If the attack hits her as a result of this reduced DV and inflicts even a single point of damage, the Scion receives a number of Legend points equal to the DV penalty she forced upon herself. (Only the DV points the player intentionally sacrificed count.)
The character can use this Boon as many times as she wishes in combat — if she is a masochist — but the Legend points granted cannot exceed the character's standard maximum.

OBSIDIAN_MUTILATION.NAME: OBSIDIAN MUTILATION
OBSIDIAN_MUTILATION.DESCRIPTION: Just as with Maguey Sting, the Scion ritually sheds her blood and receives a concomitant reward in Legend. Unlike Maguey Sting, however, this sacrifice is not limited to one health level and one Legend point per day. If her player succeeds on a Conviction roll, the character can inflict as many health levels of lethal damage on herself as she wishes, gaining a Legend point for every health level she suffers. (These points can exceed the normal maximum, but any extra points disappear after a week.) The character can perform this ritual only once per week.

JOTUNBLUT.NAME: JOTUNBLUT
JOTUNBLUT.DESCRIPTION:
“Jotunblut”, which literally means “giant's blood”, describes a quality peculiar to the Gods and Scions of the Norse pantheon. In the old days, the Norse Gods mingled with the giants from whom they took the World, mixing their ichor with the blood of their enemies. Today, that legacy breeds true in the ichor of these Gods' Scions. By shedding a measure of her blood (i.e., suffering a single health level of lethal damage) and spending Legend, a Scion can use that blood to grant a touch of the legendary strength and endurance of the giants. Mortals and animals who receive this endowment from a Scion remain loyal to that Scion thereafter, though they become rude and ill-tempered with everyone else. This loyalty lasts for a limited time and must be renewed periodically by a new infusion of the Scion's blood. If the limited time expires and the Scion does not renew the recipient's loyalty, the recipient becomes feral but retains the physical bonuses. Once that happens, any Scion with appropriate Jotunblut Boons can re-endow the feral being and claim its loyalty for herself.
Endowments granted by these Boons cannot be stacked on the same character, even if a Scion is re-endowing a feral being. They can, however, be superseded by higher-dot Boons under this Purview. That is, a Scion cannot endow the same person twice with the two-dot Boon of this Purview to give the person four free Attribute dots. (That would cost more Legend points anyway.) If he wants the person to have more free Attribute dots, he will have to re-endow that person with a Jotunblut Boon ranked at three dots or higher. If the Scion re-endows a person with a Jotunblut Boon ranked lower or equal to the last one that affected the character after that person's previous loyalty expires, the Scion claims that person's loyalty but has no effect on the recipient's Attributes.
Finally, Scions cannot use these Boons to grant free Attribute dots to (or claim the loyalty of) titanspawn, their fellow Scions, or other supernatural beings.

BESTIAL_ENDOWMENT.NAME: BESTIAL ENDOWMENT
BESTIAL_ENDOWMENT.DESCRIPTION: The Scion grants a beast a single extra dot in Strength or Stamina. The beast becomes loyal only to the Scion, who can also train it normally, but that loyalty must be renewed once every month.

HUMAN_ENDOWMENT.NAME: HUMAN ENDOWMENT
HUMAN_ENDOWMENT.DESCRIPTION: The Scion can imbue a human with two free Attribute dots that can be spent on the human's Strength and/or Stamina. The human remains loyal to the Scion for a single month, but becomes irritable around other people. A Scion cannot use this Boon on a beast.

HEROIC_ENDOWMENT.NAME: HEROIC ENDOWMENT
HEROIC_ENDOWMENT.DESCRIPTION: The Scion can now imbue a human with three free Attribute dots to be spent on the human's Strength and/or Stamina. The person remains loyal to the Scion for three months (roughly a season) and remains equally irritable with other people. A Scion cannot use this Boon on a beast.

TSUKUMO_GAMI.NAME: TSUKUMO-GAMI
TSUKUMO_GAMI.DESCRIPTION: It is a fundamental Shinto understanding that every physical object has a spirit. These spirits, known as kami, range as widely in grace and power as the objects they represent vary in size and importance. A Scion who has inherited this Purview is not only aware of these spirits but is able to coax them out of hiding and bargain with them for information and favors.

THE_WAKEFUL_SPIRIT.NAME: THE WAKEFUL SPIRIT
THE_WAKEFUL_SPIRIT.DESCRIPTION:
With a little persistence, a Scion can catch the attention of an inanimate object's spirit and speak with it for a few minutes. When she does this, the object takes on anthropomorphic features — the grain in a wooden door, for instance, might flow into the shape of a face — and speaks in a manner befitting the object's size and importance. Common and unimportant objects have stupid, semi-conscious spirits, while unique objects to which people form emotional attachments are articulate, knowledgeable, and charming.
In speaking to a spirit, a character can uncover information that the spirit has experienced directly. The spirit of a car can talk about where it has been or who has been in it. The spirit of a lamp can talk about the last time the master of the house used its light. The spirit of a wishing well can talk about how many people wasted their coins on false hope. The older and more interesting the object, the further back and more clearly its spirit can recall important information. Spirits do not easily differentiate between non-spirit beings, however, and consider it rude to talk about other spirits' goings-on if the spirits in question are doing their jobs correctly. Also, most don't pay much attention to their surroundings unless something truly unusual happens.

THE_WATCHFUL_SPIRIT.NAME: THE WATCHFUL SPIRIT
THE_WATCHFUL_SPIRIT.DESCRIPTION: The Scion can not only extract information from a kami, but also assign it to some passive task on her behalf. She can, for example, have the kami watch a specific person, watch for any titanspawn that approach, or remember and repeat anything another Scion says to it. This period of duty lasts a number of days equal to the number of successes the character accumulated on the activation roll.

THE_HELPFUL_SPIRIT.NAME: THE HELPFUL SPIRIT
THE_HELPFUL_SPIRIT.DESCRIPTION: With proper shows of respect and decorum, a Scion can convince the kami within an object to enhance that object's mundane function. In doing so, she gains a dice bonus equal to the number of Legend points she spends on the effect, which lasts a number of days equal to the number of successes on the activation roll. Whether it be anything from a weapon to a grand piano, the item must be one that requires a dice roll to use with skill. If the character uses this Boon on one of her Birthright items, she can enhance only its mundane function.

SPECIAL.DESCRIPTION: These Purviews are associated with specific Gods but are available to Scions of any heritage. Their dots are purchased in sequence, representing growing mastery of the Purview. A Scion must have a Birthright relic to use these Purviews.

MAGIC.NAME: MAGIC
MAGIC.DESCRIPTION:
In a sense, every power that a Scion's Boons, Epic Attributes, and Knacks grant him could be considered magic. However, one power seems magical even to them — namely, the ability to direct and influence the mysterious force of Fate. All Scions (and even the Gods themselves) are subject to Fate, but only a select few are graced with the power to read it and influence it.
A Scion gains a new free spell of the increased value for each new dot of the Magic Purview he obtains. Additional spells of equal or lesser value are purchased individually as general-purpose Purview Boons are (for the same bonus point or experience point cost). Some examples of spells are provided here, but in theory, the number of possible spells is limitless.
Scions with this Purview can design their own spells, but examples are given for each level of advancement. Inherent in each of these spells is the power to undo the application of the same spell by someone else. The target of a spell is automatically Fatebound to the caster (see p. 222).
Associated With: Frigg, Hera, Hermes, Huitzilopochtli, Isis, Kalfu, Loki, Odin, Tezcatlipoca, Thoth

SPELLS


Casting requires a dice roll by the casting character's player. The character must also pay a cost, listed in the spell description. If he cannot pay the cost, or does not wish to, he can perform a sacrifice instead (see the “Sacrifices” sidebar). Otherwise, he cannot cast the spell. The cost must be paid for Fate to bend. Unless otherwise noted in a spell's description, the effects of a successfully cast spell last for one scene (or one hour).

ARIADNES_THREAD.NAME: ARIADNE’S THREAD
ARIADNES_THREAD.DESCRIPTION: The caster declares a target (a person, place, or thing) and can thereafter track unerringly where that target has gone by following the disturbances it leaves in the threads of Fate. If the target is a place, the caster can always find his way back there, no matter how disoriented or lost he has become. This spell lasts one day per success rolled, but can be extended daily by spending a Legend point.

THE_UNLIDDED_EYE.NAME: THE UNLIDDED EYE
THE_UNLIDDED_EYE.DESCRIPTION: This spell allows its caster to see magic and supernatural powers that are normally invisible to mortal sight. It also faintly reveals the threads of Fate that intertwine people, revealing strong or thick threads and allowing the caster to determine the Legend score of a Scion or other supernatural being.

BONA_FORTUNA.NAME: BONA FORTUNA
BONA_FORTUNA.DESCRIPTION: The caster invokes Fortuna for a surge of good luck. Each success gives him a die he can 'spend' to add to any dice pool for any rolls he makes for the remainder of the scene. Once he spends all his Bona Fortuna successes, they are gone; he must cast this spell again if he wants more. He can distribute multiple successes as he wishes, but the maximum Fortune dice he can add to any single roll cannot exceed half his Willpower score.

EVIL_EYE.NAME: EVIL EYE
EVIL_EYE.DESCRIPTION: The caster grants another person a surge of good luck, as he might do for himself with the Bona Fortuna spell. The cost to cast this spell, however, is that the caster himself must accept a concomitant penalty at some future time (“stored” by his Legend until spent). If the player rolled three successes, granting the spell's target a pool of three dice to spend on one or more future rolls, his character suffers a -3 penalty, which he must apply all at once against a single roll — effectively, the next roll he makes for which he spends a Legend point.

TRADING_FATES.NAME: TRADING FATES
TRADING_FATES.DESCRIPTION: Meditating for an action (Speed 3) on a symbol representing his animal, the Scion assumes a metaphorical trait associated with it, creating a dice bonus for rolls involving the Attribute most closely associated with that trait. A Scion might assume the sinuous grace of a snake (Dexterity), the beauty of a peacock (Appearance), the proverbial memory of an elephant (via Intelligence), or any other justifiable trait. The bonus dice equal the number of successes on the activation roll, and the benefit lasts one action per Legend point spent upfront to fuel the Boon.

DEUS_EX_MACHINA.NAME: DEUS EX MACHINA
DEUS_EX_MACHINA.DESCRIPTION:
The caster calls for help — and Fate answers in its own way. The most unlikely — even impossible — escapes can be delivered by this spell. If the caster is hanging from a cliff by his fingernails, a sudden earthquake might cause a ledge to jut out beneath him, arresting his fall. If he is tied to a railroad track in front of a speeding train, the train might jump the track over him, continuing its path as if he weren't there. The caster cannot choose the form of help he receives; he has thrown his lot in with Fate and gets what fate brings. Basically, the Storyteller can be as dramatic and creative as he wishes, but has no obligation to be so. He can choose a rather mundane rescue if he so desires (the Scion hanging from a cliff is pulled to safety by a Boy Scout).
The caster is Fatebound to the person, place, or means of his rescue. The strength of the bond is 3, unless the caster spends extra Legend points — on a scale of one point per -1 strength — during casting to lower it (minimum strength of 1).

DEMAND_A_LABOR.NAME: DEMAND A LABOR
DEMAND_A_LABOR.DESCRIPTION:
The caster can demand that a person perform a task for him. This is called a labor, or sometimes a geas, and until the spell's target completes the task, he is not whole. Until he is victorious, he cannot spend Willpower points on any action except one that aids in the completion of his task. The difficulty of this casting depends on the type of labor requested. The caster cannot, however, demand a labor with a difficulty higher than half his Willpower score.
Difficulty Labor
1 Mundane (easy): Fetch an accessible item from a common store; perform light manual labor; write a book report
2 Mundane (hard): Fetch a hard-to-find item; perform heavy manual labor; solve a puzzle
3 Supernatural (easy): Deliver a message to a dryad; defeat a weak monster
4 Supernatural (hard): Defeat a strong monster
5*Herculean: Clean the Augean Stables; fetch an apple of the Hesperides

* Beginning Scions cannot demand a labor with a difficulty higher than 4. Only Demigods or Gods can cast such magic.
The target's player can attempt to have his character resist its compulsion during casting by rolling Willpower. If the roll obtains more successes than the casting roll, the target is unaffected by the spell. There are higher ranking levels of this spell that allow the caster to impose multiple labors on a target.

MYSTERY.NAME: MYSTERY
MYSTERY.DESCRIPTION:
The Mystery Purview represents an understanding of the interconnectedness of bizarre and apparently random events — an understanding that mortal minds are not equipped to achieve. Gods and Scions with this Purview not only recognize this interconnectedness but can read significant clues from it.
Associated With: Damballa, Dionysus, Isis, Odin, Tezcatlipoca

MYSTERY_0.NAME: MYSTERY (LEVEL 0)
MYSTERY_0.DESCRIPTION:
To use this Purview, the Scion clears her head and looks at the World around her without analysis or expectation. Based on what she sees, the character makes intuitive leaps of logic hitherto denied, as objects in the World around her trigger subconscious connections. The player then rolls her character's (Intelligence + Mystery), without adding bonus successes from Epic Intelligence. The player can then ask direct and specific questions of the Storyteller about various events that have occurred in the game — one question per success on the roll. The Storyteller need not expound on his answers (they can be quite terse and direct, in fact), but must answer them as honestly and directly as he can.
Using this Purview cannot reveal facts about things that will happen in the future, nor can a character use it to gain insights into events that do not concern her or the members of her heroic Band. The player can use this effect to gain knowledge only once per story. She can reroll a failed roll until she gets a success, but on a botch she gains no information and cannot use Mystery again until the next story.

PROPHECY.NAME: PROPHECY
PROPHECY.DESCRIPTION:
The Prophecy Purview offers the Scion who masters it glimpses of the machinations of Fate itself. The warnings of future events the Purview offers are invaluable, but the Scion who relies on them too heavily risks becoming an unwitting agent of Fate itself.
Associated With: Apollo, Bastet, Frigg, Legba, Odin, Shango, Tezcatlipoca

PROPHECY_0.NAME: PROPHECY (LEVEL 0)
PROPHECY_0.DESCRIPTION: The player of the Scion with this Purview rolls his (Intelligence + Prophecy) — without Epic Intelligence benefits — and can do so once per story. If the roll fails, nothing happens and the player can try again. If the roll succeeds, the Storyteller reveals some prophetic hints about events that will unfold in the future. These hints should pertain to significant plot points in the current story or to large overarching questions affecting the cycle as a whole. The more successes the activation roll obtains, the less obscure and more directly useful the prophetic hints should be. The Storyteller can give a number of hints equal to the number of successes on the roll, or can simply reveal a more detailed prophecy as the player gains more successes.
